column1: Squanto, the Native American who acted as a translator for the Pilgrims and helped them learn how to cultivate crops, had never come into contact with a colonist before 1621.
column8: In 1614, Tisquantum, also known as Squanto, was captured by the English and sold into slavery in Spain. In 1619, he returned to Massachusetts, only to find that his entire tribe, the Patuxet, had died of smallpox.

column1: Which Native American group shared the first Thanksgiving meal with the Pilgrims?
column8: In 1621, the Pilgrims celebrated a successful harvest with people from a Wamponoag tribe.

column1: When was Thanksgiving declared a national holiday?
column8: President Abraham Lincoln declared Thanksgiving a national holiday in 1863.

column1: When is National Mourning Day celebrated?
column8: Since 1970, Indigenous people in Massachusetts and their supporters have gathered on Cole’s Hill in Plymouth on Thanksgiving day to honor Native lives lost to genocide and protest the violence they continue to face today.

column1: Was turkey actually eaten at the first Thanksgiving?
column8: Accounts of the presence of turkey at Thanksgiving are inconclusive. While there are reports of the Pilgrims eating turkey at other points, nothing in William Bradford’s telling of the day mentions turkey specifically.
column12: Accounts of the presence of turkey at Thanksgiving are inconclusive. While there are reports of the Pilgrims eating turkey at other points, nothing in William Bradford’s telling of the day mentions turkey specifically.

column1: Before getting help from the Wampanoags, how did the Pilgrims survive their first winter?
column8: A year before their successful harvest, the Pilgrims resorted to robbing Native American graves and houses for food.
column12: A year before their successful harvest, the Pilgrims resorted to robbing Native American graves and houses for food.
column16: A year before their successful harvest, the Pilgrims resorted to robbing Native American graves and houses for food.
column18: Robbing Native people's graves and homes

column1: The entire Wampanoag tribe was killed in King Philip's War of 1675.
column8: Although over 40 percent of the Wampanoag people died in King Philip’s War, the community has survived and begun re-acquiring their tribal lands in Massachusetts and Eastern Rhode Island.
